If you're young playing video games, shopping online, or fulminating on Facebook, it's because of something called leisure time. utterances.speaker: GRAPHIC
utterances.sentences: The PC Police

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Nice. Well, first up, an academic claims some meat-based expressions could be on the chopping block, because vegans find them offensive. PETA has been pushing to change certain phrases for years and has recommendations. "Bring home the bacon" should be "bring home the bagels." And "taking the bull by the horns" becomes "taking the flowers by the thorns." So Dana, taking the flowers by the thorns doesn't really have the same ring to it, does it?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It sure doesn't. And I was waiting for the press release from PETA announcing mission accomplished, because apparently, they have succeeded in making sure that all animals are treated ethically; because now they're going to spend their time going after language. I mean, that's a lot of progress for PETA.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Greg, why all the sensitivity? Why have we become so sensitive as a nation?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: This is actually a pretty big deal. When you try -- when we talk about the PC police, it's us. It's actually human beings. It's not the -- like, we used to think "1984," Orwellian, it was going to be the government that's out to silence us and adjust our behavior. But it's actually young people on campuses. When I was growing up and when everybody was growing up, young kids didn't care about this. Their primary thing was to break rules, to take risks, to have fun. Now they are policing speech. They have become the tattlers and the hall monitors. And you can see. What do they graduate from? They graduate to media blogs. Right? They go -- they want to police language on campus. Then they go on to media blogs where they try to catch people and go, "Aha!" because they can't get a real job. They aren't creative.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Who are you referring to?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I'm referring to every media blog.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Where they all -- because they're kind of on the -- they're not doing what they want to do, so they just have to sit there and go after people who are fulfilling their dreams.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Have you ever gone on a right-wing blog? It's worse.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, they're not about -- they don't chase media. They chase people.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: All right. Up next, a crackdown on some classics. Take a listen to this. UNIDENTIFIED MALE (singing): Sha la la la la la, don't be scared. You got the mood prepared. Go on and kiss the girl.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: So an all-male a cappella group at Princeton announcing that it is temporarily scrapping the "Kiss the Girl" song from its "Little Mermaid" performance over concerns about consent and misogyny. And a controversy has erupted over this Christmas song.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: What's the sense of hurting my pride?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: I really can't stay.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Baby, don't hold out, baby.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Oh, but it's cold outside.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: It's cold outside.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: A Cleveland radio station under fire for pulling "Baby, It's Cold Outside" after a listener complained that the holiday tune was inappropriate among the #MeToo movement. Juan, haven't we just taken this too far? And also, with the "Baby, It's Cold Outside," it was cold outside. She wanted to stay to have another drink. What's wrong with that?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I don't think -- it's that he was seducing her, Lisa.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: How dare he?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I think seduction's quite intriguing, and I love the song. Greg tells me he hates it because he --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I hate duets.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes, OK. But I love the song. But I understand that they just want to be clear that, you know, you shouldn't be tricking a woman or pulling off her hat or what you --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Taking off her hat?

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: But see -- but Jesse --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That's what he did in the video. Did you see it?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Oh, my God. God forbid.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Yes, but doesn't that kind of take away a woman's agency? I mean, she chose to stay. I mean, are we sort of -- even with the "Kiss the Girl" song, are we -- what is wrong with, you know, being courted or a guy wanting to kiss a girl or going on a date? I mean, this is --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Clearly, she's not in control. She's the victim.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You know I think is sexy? Consent is sexy. I think anytime you want a woman to come stay for another drink, you have her sign a legal document. Anytime you want to move in and try to kiss her, sign a legal document.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Wait, what about the selfies.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Make it air-tight.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Selfies.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That is sexy. Consent is sexy.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: That sounds like it's going to be a great dating world in the future.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, that's how -- that's how it's working now. I mean, that's what -- that is what is happening. People are doing that. And if you don't -- and also, the thing is, you almost have to have somebody present.  Because you never know. If it's just you and this other person.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Alexa.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Alexa!

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Alexa.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Alexa is going to be the A.I. policeman.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: You're going to -- you're going to get sent, like, a text with some sort of consent form before going on dates. All right. Well, and finally, a 9-year-old scores a big win by getting a Colorado town to end its ban on snowball fights. Dane Best successfully convincing his local town officials to make it legal again to throw snowballs at people, after it was banned for nearly a decade -- or nearly a century, rather. So huge win here for freedom, right, Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, I am pro-snowball.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, I mean, this is what the Founders had in mind when they drafted the Bill of Rights.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: These are the types of -- this is like a rite of passage. You have to hit someone in the face with a snowball younger than you at a certain point in your life. And --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Bullier [SIC]!

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- and that makes that young person more resilient.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, my goodness.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And that's an important lesson.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Ask Dana. Dana is from a place that makes snowballs. She's the snowball champion.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Have I told you that my grandfather on the ranch, he did not let us throw snowballs, because he had seen -- well, he said he saw somebody's eye get taken out by one once. But here's the thing: I am pro-snowball if it means fewer snowflakes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well done.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: That's a good point. I mean, Juan, there's a lot of snowflakes out there, aren't there?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You know, I think there are a lot of people worry, in terms of the culture war, that we don't take care of each other, that we bully people, that --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Come on, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: As Jesse said -- as Jesse said, throw it at a younger, weaker soul. Come on.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I meant, like, a younger brother.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You know Juan? I admire Juan. Juan is just putting up a manufactured defense, because he knows it's exciting.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You know what? I like snowball fights. I've got no problem myself. But I think the idea that you're missing is that people worry about, you know, bullying or a culture where men can be overly aggressive and run (ph).

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK, we should do a snowball fight shoot on "The Five."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Let's follow that up, producers.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes, really.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Perfect, all right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I'm in.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Perfect. All right, well, "One More Thing" is coming up next.  Stay tuned.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: "One More Thing" -- Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, first, I do want to thank you all of you for letting me participate remotely. I appreciate still being on the show. This is what I've been waiting for, for Christmas gifts. Charles Krauthammer has a new book, "The Point of It All." It is a posthumous book, and it was completed and edited by his son, Daniel Krauthammer. It's got a lot of pieces that you may never have seen before. And you can see even more of that at CharlesKrauthammer.com. It's a really great book, wonderful essays and perfect for this time of year. Also, I'll be on "Special Report" tonight.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Excellent, excellent. All right, who's next? Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: All right. So do you remember the scene of Clark Griswold slipping while hanging from -- he's putting up Christmas decorations, slips, and then he's hanging from the edge of the roof by his fingers? Here's that scene from "National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation."

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Here's the story, come to life for Christmas 2018. The Heerlein family in Austin, Texas, put a dummy at the edge of their roof, complete with a Clark Griswold mask. One passersby thought it was real and ran over to help. Watch this.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Can you reach it? Help!

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes. The man, a veteran, even called 911. The family has now put up a sign warning people, "Hey, folks, it's just a Christmas display.  Take it easy."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I would beat the crap out of that family. If I was -- that guy went to try to do a nice thing and then you find out it was -- he was probably in panic. That guy is a hero. All right. Oh, it's my turn.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Don't be a Scrooge.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: FOX Nation, my show, "One Smart Person and Greg Gutfeld," tomorrow it premier -- second episode with the philosopher and cognitive scientist Dr. Susan Schneider. We discuss artificial intelligence and how it's going to destroy the universe. Now it's time for this. GUTFELD (singing): Animals are great! Animals are great! Animals are great!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I love hearing the moans of agony from this panel. Let's show the dueling donkeys. I love dueling donkeys. When they're dueling, this is what they do. You know what's great about dueling donkeys? Is that when they're doing this and you watch it long enough, you will get incredibly dizzy and nauseous. Much like drinking too much tequila. And when I look at dueling donkeys all I can think of is -- GUTFELD (singing): Animals are great! Animals are great! Animals are great!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Oh my God, I'm never going to stop, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You're going to reach a point where executives tell to you stop.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's true. They're going to send me home. They'll send me home.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK. Congratulations to the Young Americas Foundation. Big free- speech victory over Greg's alma mater, U.C. Berkeley. Remember when they tried to ban Ben Shapiro and there was all that craziness? Well, Berkeley lost; free speech won. They settled the lawsuit against the school.  Berkeley is going to have to pay YAF 70 G's --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- to reimburse attorneys' fees; rescind their unconstitutional high-profile speaker policy; ban the university from charging these outrageous security fees; and no more hecklers' veto. Well done. Free speech, everybody.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Excellent work. It used to be that Berkeley was on the other side of that, but not anymore.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Times have changed.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Times have changed, Jesse. Good point. I've never heard that line before.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Maybe I should be on your podcast. "One Smart Person and Greg Gutfeld."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Only if you sing "Animals Are Great!" All right, Lisa.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: I just want to give a shout-out to DHL Express's Operation Holiday Cheer. It's entering its 15th year. They're sending Christmas trees, letters, gifts over to our U.S. troops who are serving overseas. And with the help of companies like Dee's Nursery in Long Island, they have donated more than 10,000 trees and trimmings to U.S. servicemen and women stationed through Iraq and Afghanistan over the years, sending some holiday cheer to them and letting them know that we're thinking about them here in the United States and thanking them for their service.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Be great if inside the trees if they would slip, in, like beers.  Like they open up and they have a six pack of beer inside each on one.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Beers or something else that looks like trees would be a better idea.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: It could be --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That would be more camouflage, Greg.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: It could be Greg Gutfeld's -- it could be "Greg Gutfeld's Operation Holiday Cheer."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: They're just trees. They're just trees. And they open up it, and there's --

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Nothing to see here.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: -- there's beer and --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, it would be like a Greg Gutfeld tree would have jewels inside of it. You know, those --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It's so of weird to be here watching all of you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. You are like the American public.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: From a healthy distance.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Please come back soon. I can't sit next to Greg any longer.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I smell great. All right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I will be your buffer.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Never miss an episode of "The Five." "Special Report" is up next. Content and Programming Copyright 2018 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. utterances.speaker: It's not a bad thing to use George H.W. Bush's death as an excuse to make life better
utterances.utterance: less finger pointing, more handshakes. This is a rush transcript from "The Five," December 4, 2018. This copy may not be in its final form and may be updated.

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Hi, I'm Greg Gutfeld with Lisa Boothe, Juan Williams, Jesse Watters, and a thin bowl is her ice bucket, Dana Perino -- "The Five." This is video of George Herbert Walker Bush when he crashed into the sea as a young pilot. It's what we call a hero. If you're young playing video games, shopping online, or fulminating on Facebook, it's because of something called leisure time. And leisure time was brought to you by millions of men and women whose bravery in times of war made our idle activity possible. I wonder, would we even be here if it weren't for men like him? The passing of George Herbert Walker Bush reminds me of the recent passing of John McCain. It also reminds me that only losing great men and women unifies people. We try to forget a whole about the other crap. In fact, we realize much of that crap is pointless. People come and go on our planet and in our lives, and it helps to remember that all of us have something in common with the great ones. With the exception of a few chuckle buckets who use such events to score political points. It's actually a share loss that reveals how we really are. None of us tweets in the face of death. Kinder and gentler, remember those words? It's a return to the baseline of human goodness. A great person dies and we can observe the rituals with reverence and respect, as though it's second nature. God help those who can't. It's possible best to ignore them. So for this week, it's not a bad thing to use this passing of a great man as an excuse to make life better, less finger-pointing, more handshakes. I'm sure in time we'll get back to our tribes, but for now let's do the guy a favor. Be kind and gentle in case he's watching. So, Dana, I'm sitting, actually, in your chair which I feel quite strange.

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: So do I.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. I don't like being this close to Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yep. Stop touching me under the table.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So, Dana, your -- the reverence lasted ten seconds.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm sorry.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I started it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. Dana, you're in D.C. -- the state funeral tomorrow, what are your thoughts? Anything that moved you particularly today?

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Yes. Well, it's obviously an honor to be here and to be able to have known them and to talk about them. I thought your monologue was spot on, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Spot bloody on. Very good. A couple of things that touched me today, I got a chance to interview Vice President Dan Quayle --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- and to look back in 1988 when he gave the convention speech then. And, of course, you know, I remember that time. I'm sure you guys do, too. Maybe Jesse doesn't, might be too young. Maybe Lisa Boothe wasn't paying attention there because she's so young as well. But it does -- you realize that things change. Parties evolve. People have a way of sort of forgetting what things were like back then. So moments like this allow you a chance to pause. The moment that really touched me today though was when Senator Bob Dole --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- went to the capital. He's 95 years old. And as you see there, he is helped by an assistant to stand so that he could properly and in his way pay his respects to George H.W. Bush, who was a very good friend of his. Of course, they were competitors but friendly competitors. But, Greg, I think it was last week we were talking about the greatest generation. I'm sorry, actually, it was Andy Ferguson's piece --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- he was a friend of yours and a speech writer for George H.W. Bush, and he wrote about a speech he had to give in which, in 1992 and during his reelection, the political consultant said don't talk about his war service. Don't let him talk about his war service because it will make him look too old --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- in comparison to Bill Clinton. Then, four weeks before the election, the political consultants changed their mind and think, oh, wait, maybe we should highlight his war service. And he writes this speech, at the end of it he says -- in the article he wrote, Ferguson says, nearly all of them are gone now. And I think maybe that's why it feels very poignant --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- like this greatest generation, we're having to say goodbye to them.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's true. It's not just Mr. Bush, it's who he symbolizes, an entire -- millions of men that are no longer here. Juan, you worked for -- I mean, you're at the Post in '88? I mean, you probably ran into President Bush when he was president or vice president.

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: He was vice president, that's when I spend most of the time with him was flying around the country going to Republican events to try to help get Ronald Reagan reelected, Greg. And so I had a wonderful time. It was kind of like, you know, being at the feet of the master because you talk about a political -- he had been head of the Republican National Committee in addition to running twice for senate unsuccessfully, but then holding a house seat twice from Houston. So he had been through a lot politically. He knew all the political leadership going back to the Goldwater days of '64. And you talk about a Republican Party expert in terms of -- I was just saying, you know, he's famous for writing notes to people and I'm sure Dana has a ton. I have some. But he would write notes to all these party leaders so that they felt that they had a personal relationship with him. And the axiom here was don't call somebody up to ask a favor, a political favor, a personal favor, right out of the box without saying how are you doing? Who are you? How are the kids? And that's the relationship he had. So that even people who disagreed with him, specifically, I would guess, you know, in this day of tribes as you say, Greg, the Democrats, oh, my gosh, Democrats had a pretty good relationship. I mean, didn't always come to good political ends because remember in terms of the budget deal where he allowed taxes to be raised in order to lower the deficit, it was then held against him by some in the party, especially the far right, the Newt Gingrich types who said, oh, you know, you're breaking your pledge not to raise taxes. Read my lips, no new taxes. But this is a, you know, an example, I keep saying that I would hold up to my children as the kind of person that you want to be. Someone who is about public service, love of country, love of family, just a -- and treated people as individuals, not as, gee, I'm George H.W. Bush, and who are you?  No, it was like tell me about you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Jesse, thoughts?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Just some personal reflections because I kind of came up under the age of Bush. You know, he was the vice presidency when I was young, and then his presidency, and then his son's presidency, kind of form to, I thought, a great statesman in America would be. Just a few things come to mind, humility, dignity, class and love. You think about he oversaw America winning the cold war. That was a time where he could have said America just beat our chests and gloat and spike the football. Instead, he didn't. And he said absolutely nothing. And that silence was very important at that time and that was a very powerful moment. I think he was, you know, raised in the prep school, boarding school era where, you know, good sportsmanship is drilled into you. And he always won with class and dignity. Also when he kicked Saddam out of Kuwait, he had an opportunity to rush to Baghdad and overthrow the entire government. And he was humble enough to know the limitations of American military power. And I think everyone, Republicans and Democrats, look back at that and say that was a very wise and humble and noble decision. Juan picked up on a few things. The personal relationships he had with people, professional relationships, friendships, he really conducted it in a classy way. He communicated on stationary or picking up the phone. And he did that for so many decades that he generated so much goodwill. And towards the end, the Republican Party was the party of Bush. The rolodex, all of the people that he knew, the networks across the entire country, just had so much honor and reverence for him and his family that when he called and asked for something it was sure. It wasn't a political favor. It was you're doing something for a friend. And then lastly, love. In terms of his relationship with Barbara and his sons publicly, at least, you'd think a man of his generation wouldn't be conditioned to show that kind of affection towards other people, especially his family in public.  But his love and affection, the way he displayed it was very modern. He wasn't afraid of embracing people and crying and articulating that love.  And I think every father and every son in this country should look at the relationship that he had with his sons and say that is how a true father- son relationship should be.

utterances.speaker: LISA BOOTHE, GUEST CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Was going to say, I found myself this week reading his letters, and I think there's been so much talk about his integrity, kindness, the kind of man he was. And if you read his letters, you can see it. And, you know, the written word always lasts so much longer than, you know, what you say on TV, or what you say during a debate, or what have you. And that's a beautiful thing for him because what a great legacy to leave behind. And, you know, Vice President Mike Pence talked about this yesterday when the former president -- when he wrote a letter to his son when he landed his first tail hook landing as a marine aviator and saying that he shares the pride that Mike Pence has in his son. You look at the letter he left Bill Clinton saying that you're our president, I am rooting for you, even though he defeated him and he was a one term president. What a beautiful thing to have that sort of character to leave that message for Bill Clinton. You look at the love letters to Barbara and what a beautiful, loving relationship that they had as a couple. The letter that he wrote about his daughter Robin who they've lost, and talking about the fact that she's always going to remain with them. So just all these letters, what a beautiful legacy for him to leave behind for future Americans to see the kind of integrity that the man had.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So, Dana, what's going to happen tomorrow at the funeral?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, you'll have eulogies from George W. Bush. I think that one will be hard for me to get through because, you know, I'm quite close to him, and as Christopher Buckley, another speechwriter wrote, that they might have been New England roots but they have the tear ducts of a Sicilian grandmother. Then you have Brian Mulroney who was a prime minister of Canada, one of 41's best friends on the world stage. Former Senator Alan Simpson from the great state of Wyoming will also eulogize him, and then it will be finalized with John Meacham, you know, the historian who wrote so much about him. The last thing I would say is something that Greg -- I think you and I said this several times, 41 really embodied this and we should all keep this in mind. Politics might be what we do, but it is not who we are.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. Thanks, Dana. Is Mueller finally ready to wrap up his investigation? The latest development in the Russia probe, that's next.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: New signs of Robert Mueller so called witch hunt is reportedly close to wrapping up. Yahoo News says the special counsel's legal team told President Trump's attorneys that they are, quote, tying up loose ends in the Russia investigation. This comes as new court filings due today on former national security advisor Michael Flynn could offer a road map to the Mueller findings. All right, so we're waiting the sentencing memo, Lisa. We have no idea what's going to be in it, but there's a lot of speculation. One of the things we do know is that James Comey did tell congressional investigators that he didn't think Flynn intentionally lied when the feds questioned him.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: And that's been something that's been in the back of my mind this entire time regarding Flynn. Because you're right, Chairman Chuck Grassley of the judiciary committee has said that when Comey met with congressional investigators, the investigators led them to believe that they didn't think Flynn had lied. And then Mueller takes over the special counsel investigation and then Flynn pleads to lying and pleads guilty to lying.  So -- and then also, Chairman Grassley has been on DOJ and the FBI to, one, give them the 302's with the interview that they conducted with Flynn so that they could see what kind of questions were, what Flynn said. And they've also asked for the transcript of Flynn's conversation with the former ambassador, Kislyak, as well. None of those things have been provided to the chairman yet. So I have a big question about that, did Flynn actually lie and that the tactics -- I think it also speaks to sort of the tactics of Mueller as well. Those hard-nose tactics.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right. And speaking of hard-nosed tactics, Cohen the former attorney for President Trump, do to be sentenced next week. And, Juan, it looks like he's caught up in some Trump Tower that doesn't even exist in Moscow. Somehow there's a scandal there, but he's facing hard time as well.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: How's that, whistling past the graveyard going for you, Jesse?

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: I mean, you're a great whistler.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: He's great. He's great. I tell you, he does it every day, Lisa. Whistling past what is obvious -- by the way, before we get going, can I ask Greg a question?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Sure.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Who is scot-free? Because I see that President Trump is tweeting that Cohen should get maximum sentence and not get away, and then he puts in uppercase --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think that's -- cousins.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah, exactly. All I know -- it's always great to see liberals criticize people over misspelling words.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It wasn't misspelled.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I think there's enough to go around.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: He had this twitter fury this morning. He went over not only Cohen, but then he said that Manafort -- was it Manafort or Roger Stone had guts?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Stone --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Stone asked Scott because he won't testify. He won't turn on him. I mean, what is -- is that obstruction of justice or what?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, I don't think it is.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know what's interesting? Listening to Juan and listening to other networks, it's like watching someone describe a drug trip that you're not on. They're just seeing things. It's hallucinations, impeachment, resignation, jail time. It's been a two-year long acid trip and it's not the good acid. And then the media, to them -- to the media it's almost like Christmas. This is their Christmas because, you know, they don't really believe in the stuff anyway. So they're at the stage now where they're hanging the stockings and they're looking under the bed and the closets for all the presents. But the bottomline, they're never going to be happy unless they get this guy out because they're still suffering from being beaten and humiliated two years ago.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You don't know what Mueller is going to say.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Clean coal.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I agree. We don't know what he's going to say. So I'm not leaping to any conclusions.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, you would never do that --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, but I will say -- I will say, boy, when you see the kind of fury in his tweet -- tweeting this morning --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- like, wow, something is happening --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: This is old news. Every day you're surprised by his tweets. To me, it's just like checking the weather. It's like, ah, it's 49 degrees and there's a tweet.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Did Juan just leap to a conclusion? You've just told you say we shouldn't leap to conclusion, but then you're reading his tweets and concluding something.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Let's go to someone who has never been on an acid trip, Dana Perino in Washington, D.C. Dana, close it out for us, the Mueller investigation hopefully winding down.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well -- so the Yahoo reporter that did that piece saying it was about to wrap up, as Michael Isikoff -- way back when, when I worked at the justice department, he was with -- I think it was Newsweek or Time Magazine, and when we were spokespeople for the justice department, you could almost count every Friday night at 5 o'clock, Michael Isikoff would call and say, yeah, we're about to drop a big story on you guys on Sunday.  So, he's got very good sources. You know, follow him, pay attention to it.  And the other thing I would say is, if they are trying to wrap it up, everyone just put on your seat belt, there's going to be some turbulence before this thing is landed, but the plane will safely land and everyone will be able to move on.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They'll never move on, Dana. They're never going to move on.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, then they can sit behind on the tarmac.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: There you go. They can take the bus.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That tarmac. Maybe Bill will be there with Loretta. All right, President Trump ripping Democrats after caravan migrants breached the border. Hear what he's saying, up next.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The crisis at the border apparently getting worse, dozens of migrants in Tijuana scaling a 10-foot fence after reportedly becoming frustrated with the slow asylum process. Meanwhile, this new video shows migrant parents dropping two small children over an 18-foot high barrier.  And President Trump, he's calling on Democrats to fund the wall while claiming illegal immigration cause the country $250 billion a year. Now, everybody is saying that's not true, about the $250 billion, but let's leave it alone. What do you make, Lisa, of the idea that we could, in fact, have some kind of delay funding bill so it would delay the potential for closing down the government right now.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Well, if you're President Trump, now is the time to try to push for border funding or sort of some changes to our immigration laws. He certainly not going to get it next congress when Democrats take over. So I think he's sort of leveraging the opportunity now. I don't know if he's going to get it or not, but I sure think when you're seeing people break the law and illegally entering the United States like we're seeing now, and also what we saw most recently with almost a thousand people trying to rush the Southern border, it sure makes President Trump's point for needing -- boosting border security along the southern border. We also have that Yale study most recently saying that the numbers are probably closer to 22 million illegal immigrants living in the United States. So, we already can't solve the problem of all these people living here illegally, why would we want to continue to exacerbate the problem, which I think this all makes the point for the wall.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Dana, what do you think about the Democrats' position that they're not going to give the president even what Chuck Schumer, the senate minority leader is offering, which is 1.5. You see the Democrats, especially -- surprise that this people from Texas, Henry Cuellar are saying, no, we gave him money last year and this -- I think a Nita Lowey from New York said this is waste -- a wasteful wall. What do you make of this?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think the funding discussion is -- well, as you described it earlier, whistling past the graveyard. Look at these images. You look at what's happening in Tijuana. Look at the elected officials there saying we're going to need some help here, folks. This is a bigger story than just like the wall funding. I think that -- I don't think the government will shut down. And besides, the Republican congress working with the White House was able to get so much done on the spending front up to now.  So a lot of those spending bills are already done. It only affects about 25 percent of the government if it does happen. I don't think it will come to that. I think the president will end up having a compromise. But talk about whistling past the graveyard. If the Democrats don't realize images like this sears into the minds of people. You see children being drop that far.  It's not ending well for the caravan participants or the -- I don't know what we want to call them, but the caravan-ers -- they are putting children lives in danger. I understand that they care about their kids, that they want to get something done, but the American people are not going to stand for this, and Democrats better figure this out, figure out a way to get past their far left and come to the table with President Trump on it, or else they're going to find more losses in 2020.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And, Jesse, the president, in fact, said this issue is a total political winner and he's willing to stand against the Democrats even in the face of, you know, all the controversy about separating children from parents, gassing, tear gassing children and adults and their parents. What do you make -- do you think it's a political winner for Republicans?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, I do. It does have a risk of becoming like his Gitmo.  Remember when Obama for eight years says I'm going to close Gitmo. He ran on closing Gitmo. And eight years later, he never closed it. You get to a certain point where you have to see visually a wall being constructed or else you realize this thing is not happening. I will -- I want to do something with you, Juan.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, my God, no.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wait a second, is this like when you were touching Greg?

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: We're on live television, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: There's going to be no touching. No touching.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Good. Good.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I have three questions for you.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Just follow along logically. I believe at the end of these questions, you will want a wall.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK, ready? Do you believe in borders?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK. Good, good. Do you believe currently the border is secure?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, wrong. Because you just showed visuals of people dropping babies over the wall, of people shimmying through the holes in the wall, and if you have half a million people coming through every year --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wait a second.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- that means the border is not secure.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, first of all, the number of people coming across the border is way down even -- despite that. But, secondly, if you see people -- but if you see people jumping -- is that mean that we need a wall?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: If someone is tunneling under your house, do you think your house is secure?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, that's what I'm saying, a wall is not going to do --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- a wall is not going to do the job.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK. Juan, you're failing the basic logic --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The answer to the question is the borders secure. Everybody sees on the screen of the people dropping kids --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's dangerous. That's not a wall.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The answer is no. Third question, final question --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- do you believe walls enhance security?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan, you have to use logic here.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Let me give you an example of why you're wrong.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Just one.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Sure.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right. A lot of the illegal immigration was coming through for many, many years in the Tucson sector, OK? And what do they do in Tucson, they built up all the fences, and now it's funneled all the illegal immigration crossings to the Rio Grande Valley in Texas. So, can't you build a border wall there and then funneled the crossings to a place where the border patrol can safely apprehend them?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Just like they moved from one spot, they moved to another spot?  Keep in mind --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You squeeze them.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Keep in mind, that's not the source of most illegal immigration in the country.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Most of it is people overstaying visas who fly in, in airplanes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan wants a wall.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, yes. I agree with you, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Thank you. That's all I wanted to hear.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I agree that this is a crazy conversation in America.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: I don't know anyone --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, it is, because we were talking in the B-block how the media was suffering from a collective drug trip in which they were seeing and hallucinating things. This is actually the opposite. When you actually see things happening, and they're denying it. They're denying with their eyes see. Remember when Joe Scarborough, a.k.a. Mr. Bozo Face, said that -- he was comparing the caravan, the migrants coming, to Martians in his backyard.  So apparently, he has Martians. The Martians have landed. And then you have this other weird part where the media is blaming Donald Trump for the caravan, thousands of people coming. Only the left could hear Trump say, "You better not come" and hear "He's telling them to come!"  No, he was telling them don't come. It's not going to end well. To quote Dana, it's not going to end well. And left are, "Oh, it's obviously his fault. He's encouraging them to come." No, it was manufactured. It was a manufactured march created by activist groups in the media. And now we're seeing it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think there were people in desperate straits down in Central America.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: A lot -- there's desperate straits everywhere.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Juan, you never let anyone have the last word.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I was going to let you have it, if you want it last, go right --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I don't want the -- I don't want the last word. I want you to tease so I can do my segment.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So there. You see that, Jesse? The wall is talking back to us.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: She's the wall.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Up next.

utterances.speaker: FORMER VICE PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN
utterances.utterance: A man who will be the next president of the United States, Barack America [SIC].

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Will moments like these --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Barack America? I never saw that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- stop Joe Biden from running for president? That, plus Michael Avenatti's big, big, big announcement about 2020 right here on "The Five."

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Joe Biden teasing a potential 2020 run by saying he's, quote, "the most qualified person in the country" to be president. The former VP also admitting that he's a, quote, "gaffe machine" for memorable moments like these.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.utterance: My mother believed and my father believed that if I wanted to be president of the United States, I could be. I could be vice president. This is a big (EXPLETIVE DELETED) deal. His mom lived in Long Island for ten years or so, God rest her soul. And - - although, she's -- wait, your mom's -- your mom's still alive. It's your dad passed. God bless her soul. Chuck Graham, state senator's here. Chuck. Stand up, Chuck. Let them see you. Oh, God love you. What am I talking about? A man who will be the next president of the United States, Barack America. They're going to put you all back in chains.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I have a feeling we might be seeing that montage a while. Some of those gaffes are certainly endearing. Greg, let me ask you this. Is the Democratic Party looking for the most qualified?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, not at all. He might be the most qualified, but he's an old white male, and that is the Ford Pinto of candidates in 2018. The preferred model has -- is going to be based on a combination of identity. You know, the interesting thing, though, the difference between Biden and Trump is that Biden is kind of an old-school politician. His mistakes are old-school. His cadences are old-school. The glad-handing. The -- he's a kissing baby politician. Trump isn't like that. And if you put these two guys up against each other, they may be similar in age, but in terms of temperament and energy, Donald Trump will walk all over him. And I think the Democrats know that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Jesse, just this week in Iowa, they polled a bunch of Democrats there, and they asked, you know, "What are you looking for? You know, are you looking for experience and et cetera?" What a lot of them said is they wanted somebody younger, somebody from the younger generation. Do you think that will emerge?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, it has to. Well, everyone is younger than Joe Biden, so I don't think it's really an issue.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Wait, not Bernie.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I was going to say. That's pretty close.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's true. I stand corrected.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, maybe Bernie's younger.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I stand corrected. Everybody looks -- looks old. So I think the issue is he only has one card to play. He is a longtime Washington politician that has a lot of experience in Washington. He can't change that, so he has to say, "I'm experienced." He has to say, "I know what I'm doing." And he's going to say, "I'm going to come back to Washington, restore dignity to the White House, restore order, restore normalcy, and repair all the institutions that Donald Trump has destroyed."  And --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wait a second. I thought you were a Trump supporter.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm saying that that's his pitch, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, I thought --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's his pitch.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I got lost there.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's his pitch. And so what he's doing is saying, "I'm admitting I'm a gaffe machine. But my gaffes are not gaffes," because what do they say a gaffe is in Washington? When a politician tells the truth.  So he's saying, "I'm so honest, I make a lot of gaffes." And he's trying to own it. The problem with him, it's not all gaffes. He's got a terrible voting record. He's got terrible instincts. He's got no charisma, no base, can't raise a lot of money. That's not really his -- his problem.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And to that point, Juan, I wanted to ask you this. So if Joe Biden, who says he's the most qualified, he's going to go out there, there's a big part of the party that has moved very far left. And Joe Biden would have to explain to them why he was on the other side of all of those issues for the last 30 years.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, you know, the interesting thing is that Joe Biden is in the clear lead in this poll that was done, I think, Harvard Harris; it was published in The Hill. In second place was Bernie Sanders. So I think what they're looking for is almost in the model, Dana -- I think this might appeal to you -- of a George H.W. Bush. Someone with experience, someone who knows Washington, knows how the game is played. I, by the way, differ with my colleagues here. I think that Biden and Sanders would -- boy, they'd love to trade punches with Donald Trump.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's like the two old guys from "The Muppets."

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, yes, OK. What is Donald Trump, then? I don't know.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We're talking about energy levels.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes. And then you get Mike Bloomberg and people like that.  Mike Bloomberg would have trouble, Dana, on something like Stop and Frisk and policy. Everybody's going to have issues.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's true.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But you know, I remember Ronald Reagan's favorite saying when he was debating against, who was he debating, Mondale? When he says, "I'm not going to hold my opponent's youth and inexperience against him."

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And so I think some of these folks that you say are older that might have great appeal.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes. Look, I'm for -- I'm not being ageist here. I do want to mention one thing, and Lisa, I'll get your comment on this.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Sure.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And then I know Greg wants to weigh in. Michael Avenatti, the creepy you know what lawyer, announcing today that he is not going to run in 2020. The Democrats probably getting a pass on that one.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: I think they're all probably saying, "Thank God." Right? But look, regarding Joe Biden, I think he would actually give President Trump a run for his money in a general election, particularly in places like Macomb County, those blue-collar areas that President Trump did so well. But the problem for Joe Biden is I don't think he can get there, because Democrats are going to have a really crowded primary field, just like Republicans did. And the reason why President Trump was able to make his way through that crowded primary field was because he was so vastly different than the other candidates that were in the mix. Joe Biden isn't that different than, you know, the -- maybe 30-something candidates that are going to run. So I think we actually may end up seeing someone that breaks through that Democrat primary field that we're not talking about right now there -- that isn't even on the radar.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's going to be fun to watch.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Yes, exactly. It will be a lot of fun.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Greg, tell me what you think about Avenatti.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The unfairness of Avenatti is that he was accused of something, and the accusation was alone enough to derail his future ambitions. It's appropriate justice, given the fact that he spearheaded a movement to derail the career by weaponizing accusations untethered to evidence. So that's how the world works.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Boom. Indeed. I'm going to give you the last word on that. All right. Up next, why The Little Mermaid and the song "Baby, It's Cold Outside" are under attack.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Jesse likes this song. Get ready, because the PC police are out in full force yet again.

utterances.speaker: GRAPHIC
utterances.utterance: The PC Police

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Nice. Well, first up, an academic claims some meat-based expressions could be on the chopping block, because vegans find them offensive. PETA has been pushing to change certain phrases for years and has recommendations. "Bring home the bacon" should be "bring home the bagels." And "taking the bull by the horns" becomes "taking the flowers by the thorns." So Dana, taking the flowers by the thorns doesn't really have the same ring to it, does it?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It sure doesn't. And I was waiting for the press release from PETA announcing mission accomplished, because apparently, they have succeeded in making sure that all animals are treated ethically; because now they're going to spend their time going after language. I mean, that's a lot of progress for PETA.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Greg, why all the sensitivity? Why have we become so sensitive as a nation?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: This is actually a pretty big deal. When you try -- when we talk about the PC police, it's us. It's actually human beings. It's not the -- like, we used to think "1984," Orwellian, it was going to be the government that's out to silence us and adjust our behavior. But it's actually young people on campuses. When I was growing up and when everybody was growing up, young kids didn't care about this. Their primary thing was to break rules, to take risks, to have fun. Now they are policing speech. They have become the tattlers and the hall monitors. And you can see. What do they graduate from? They graduate to media blogs. Right? They go -- they want to police language on campus. Then they go on to media blogs where they try to catch people and go, "Aha!" because they can't get a real job. They aren't creative.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Who are you referring to?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm referring to every media blog.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Where they all -- because they're kind of on the -- they're not doing what they want to do, so they just have to sit there and go after people who are fulfilling their dreams.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Have you ever gone on a right-wing blog? It's worse.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, they're not about -- they don't chase media. They chase people.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: All right. Up next, a crackdown on some classics. Take a listen to this.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE (singing)
utterances.utterance: Sha la la la la la, don't be scared. You got the mood prepared. Go on and kiss the girl.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: So an all-male a cappella group at Princeton announcing that it is temporarily scrapping the "Kiss the Girl" song from its "Little Mermaid" performance over concerns about consent and misogyny. And a controversy has erupted over this Christmas song.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: What's the sense of hurting my pride?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: I really can't stay.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Baby, don't hold out, baby.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Oh, but it's cold outside.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: It's cold outside.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: A Cleveland radio station under fire for pulling "Baby, It's Cold Outside" after a listener complained that the holiday tune was inappropriate among the #MeToo movement. Juan, haven't we just taken this too far? And also, with the "Baby, It's Cold Outside," it was cold outside. She wanted to stay to have another drink. What's wrong with that?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't think -- it's that he was seducing her, Lisa.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: How dare he?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think seduction's quite intriguing, and I love the song. Greg tells me he hates it because he --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I hate duets.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, OK. But I love the song. But I understand that they just want to be clear that, you know, you shouldn't be tricking a woman or pulling off her hat or what you --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Taking off her hat?

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: But see -- but Jesse --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's what he did in the video. Did you see it?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, my God. God forbid.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Yes, but doesn't that kind of take away a woman's agency? I mean, she chose to stay. I mean, are we sort of -- even with the "Kiss the Girl" song, are we -- what is wrong with, you know, being courted or a guy wanting to kiss a girl or going on a date? I mean, this is --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Clearly, she's not in control. She's the victim.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You know I think is sexy? Consent is sexy. I think anytime you want a woman to come stay for another drink, you have her sign a legal document. Anytime you want to move in and try to kiss her, sign a legal document.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wait, what about the selfies.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Make it air-tight.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Selfies.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That is sexy. Consent is sexy.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: That sounds like it's going to be a great dating world in the future.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, that's how -- that's how it's working now. I mean, that's what -- that is what is happening. People are doing that. And if you don't -- and also, the thing is, you almost have to have somebody present.  Because you never know. If it's just you and this other person.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Alexa.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Alexa!

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Alexa.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Alexa is going to be the A.I. policeman.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: You're going to -- you're going to get sent, like, a text with some sort of consent form before going on dates. All right. Well, and finally, a 9-year-old scores a big win by getting a Colorado town to end its ban on snowball fights. Dane Best successfully convincing his local town officials to make it legal again to throw snowballs at people, after it was banned for nearly a decade -- or nearly a century, rather. So huge win here for freedom, right, Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, I am pro-snowball.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, I mean, this is what the Founders had in mind when they drafted the Bill of Rights.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: These are the types of -- this is like a rite of passage. You have to hit someone in the face with a snowball younger than you at a certain point in your life. And --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Bullier [SIC]!

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- and that makes that young person more resilient.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, my goodness.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And that's an important lesson.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Ask Dana. Dana is from a place that makes snowballs. She's the snowball champion.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Have I told you that my grandfather on the ranch, he did not let us throw snowballs, because he had seen -- well, he said he saw somebody's eye get taken out by one once.

utterances.speaker: But here's the thing
utterances.utterance: I am pro-snowball if it means fewer snowflakes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well done.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: That's a good point. I mean, Juan, there's a lot of snowflakes out there, aren't there?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know, I think there are a lot of people worry, in terms of the culture war, that we don't take care of each other, that we bully people, that --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Come on, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: As Jesse said -- as Jesse said, throw it at a younger, weaker soul. Come on.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I meant, like, a younger brother.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know Juan? I admire Juan. Juan is just putting up a manufactured defense, because he knows it's exciting.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know what? I like snowball fights. I've got no problem myself. But I think the idea that you're missing is that people worry about, you know, bullying or a culture where men can be overly aggressive and run (ph).

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK, we should do a snowball fight shoot on "The Five."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Let's follow that up, producers.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, really.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Perfect, all right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I'm in.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Perfect. All right, well, "One More Thing" is coming up next.  Stay tuned.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: "One More Thing" -- Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, first, I do want to thank you all of you for letting me participate remotely. I appreciate still being on the show. This is what I've been waiting for, for Christmas gifts. Charles Krauthammer has a new book, "The Point of It All." It is a posthumous book, and it was completed and edited by his son, Daniel Krauthammer. It's got a lot of pieces that you may never have seen before. And you can see even more of that at CharlesKrauthammer.com. It's a really great book, wonderful essays and perfect for this time of year. Also, I'll be on "Special Report" tonight.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Excellent, excellent. All right, who's next? Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right. So do you remember the scene of Clark Griswold slipping while hanging from -- he's putting up Christmas decorations, slips, and then he's hanging from the edge of the roof by his fingers? Here's that scene from "National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation."

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Here's the story, come to life for Christmas 2018. The Heerlein family in Austin, Texas, put a dummy at the edge of their roof, complete with a Clark Griswold mask. One passersby thought it was real and ran over to help. Watch this.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Can you reach it? Help!

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes. The man, a veteran, even called 911. The family has now put up a sign warning people, "Hey, folks, it's just a Christmas display.  Take it easy."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I would beat the crap out of that family. If I was -- that guy went to try to do a nice thing and then you find out it was -- he was probably in panic. That guy is a hero. All right. Oh, it's my turn.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Don't be a Scrooge.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: FOX Nation, my show, "One Smart Person and Greg Gutfeld," tomorrow it premier -- second episode with the philosopher and cognitive scientist Dr. Susan Schneider. We discuss artificial intelligence and how it's going to destroy the universe. Now it's time for this.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD (singing)
utterances.utterance: Animals are great! Animals are great! Animals are great!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I love hearing the moans of agony from this panel. Let's show the dueling donkeys. I love dueling donkeys. When they're dueling, this is what they do. You know what's great about dueling donkeys? Is that when they're doing this and you watch it long enough, you will get incredibly dizzy and nauseous. Much like drinking too much tequila. And when I look at dueling donkeys all I can think of is --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD (singing)
utterances.utterance: Animals are great! Animals are great! Animals are great!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh my God, I'm never going to stop, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You're going to reach a point where executives tell to you stop.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's true. They're going to send me home. They'll send me home.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK. Congratulations to the Young Americas Foundation. Big free- speech victory over Greg's alma mater, U.C. Berkeley. Remember when they tried to ban Ben Shapiro and there was all that craziness? Well, Berkeley lost; free speech won. They settled the lawsuit against the school.  Berkeley is going to have to pay YAF 70 G's --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- to reimburse attorneys' fees; rescind their unconstitutional high-profile speaker policy; ban the university from charging these outrageous security fees; and no more hecklers' veto. Well done. Free speech, everybody.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Excellent work. It used to be that Berkeley was on the other side of that, but not anymore.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Times have changed.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Times have changed, Jesse. Good point. I've never heard that line before.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Maybe I should be on your podcast. "One Smart Person and Greg Gutfeld."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Only if you sing "Animals Are Great!" All right, Lisa.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: I just want to give a shout-out to DHL Express's Operation Holiday Cheer. It's entering its 15th year. They're sending Christmas trees, letters, gifts over to our U.S. troops who are serving overseas. And with the help of companies like Dee's Nursery in Long Island, they have donated more than 10,000 trees and trimmings to U.S. servicemen and women stationed through Iraq and Afghanistan over the years, sending some holiday cheer to them and letting them know that we're thinking about them here in the United States and thanking them for their service.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Be great if inside the trees if they would slip, in, like beers.  Like they open up and they have a six pack of beer inside each on one.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Beers or something else that looks like trees would be a better idea.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: It could be --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That would be more camouflage, Greg.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: It could be Greg Gutfeld's -- it could be "Greg Gutfeld's Operation Holiday Cheer."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They're just trees. They're just trees. And they open up it, and there's --

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Nothing to see here.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- there's beer and --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, it would be like a Greg Gutfeld tree would have jewels inside of it. You know, those --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's so of weird to be here watching all of you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. You are like the American public.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: From a healthy distance.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Please come back soon. I can't sit next to Greg any longer.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I smell great. All right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I will be your buffer.
